segments.text: Dr. Robert Chapman, December 4th, 1985.
Okay.
I was a hospital commander at the NANG, the hospital there, the Air Force Hospital.
And in addition, we had the 22nd Casualty Staging Flight, which was responsible for air-backing everybody from the Northern Theater out in I-Corps.
At that time,
I was not practicing as an anesthesiologist, but I also have my boards in aerospace medicine.
And I was as much concerned with the

medical, the total medical management, everything from environmental medicine to the air vac business, and this is why I spent a fair amount of my time, not just in, just dealing with patients who did that, too.
Now, what specific questions did you, do you have in mind?
To begin with, if you could tell me how you got into the military service.
Well, I was a career military officer.
As a matter of fact, I retired from the Air Force in 1978, but I came in under the senior medical student program in 1958.
I've had a lot of experience with the Air Force.
My dad was a
So Brown Shoe Army, 88 Air Force later became the Air Force.
So I grew up moving around from pillar to post and all that sort of thing.
I always enjoyed flying.
And so I got interested in the military as a career.
Is that enough on that one?
Mm-hmm.
And what years were you actually in Vietnam?
I went to Vietnam in 1975.
One, 372, the time of the last big Tet Offensive.
Was it the case that with most doctors there just for like a year at a time?
I know all three of the people I've interviewed have just been there a year.
That was the standard military tour, was a year at a time.
There were very few physicians that went back for more than one tour.
I can think of only maybe one.
There were other line officers who went back for more than one, because at that time it was the only war going, and they all thought it was a great way to enhance their career, find new combat.
And you mentioned you were stationed in Denain.
What type of hospital?
Was it one of the big regional hospitals?
No, this was a small base hospital.
We had two regional hospitals, the 95th and back, which was an Army hospital about seven miles away.
And for a while we had a Navy hospital ship that was right in Da Nang Harbor, but it moved out just as I got there.
So we basically, for our neurosurgery and so forth, we had that.
We had a 100-bed casualty staging unit, which received casualties from
all through I-Corps, from way on south down to almost to about a third of the way down to Cameron.
And the casualties were, after they were processed, they were processed through us, and then we, they were vacuumed out.
mostly to Clark, some to Cadena, some to Japan.
And what rank did you achieve in the North?
I was a colonel.
I was an lieutenant colonel at the time.
How do you think the, what was the general condition of the hospitals in Vietnam?
The hospitals we were in, much like Cameron, they were prefabricated
The equipment was pretty good, and considering the shape of the rest of the buildings in Vietnam, these hospitals were pretty good.
We went through a typhoon there that did some significant amount of damage to our particular building, but the facilities there were not bad at all.

pleasant atmosphere to work in as pleasant as can be considering the uh there's no by no stretch of the imagination can you be called pull over to some base where you're restricted to the base because everything else is you're running danger getting shot at being rocketed three or four times a week i mean there's no way you can make that pleasant but all things considered um
Compared with some of the other places in Vietnam, it wasn't all that bad, except maybe down around Saigon.
We used to go down to Saigon for R&R, to Cam Ranh, too.
Cam Ranh was relatively pleasant.
Have you ever watched MASH, the TV show?
Yeah.
How did the situation there compare to life on MASH?
Well, MASH is a comedy show.
And there are some things, some of the little irritating things that go on with the communications and problems with headquarters sometimes and stuff like that.
I thought that, number one, I think the dedication of the people that were there was very similar to mine.
But a lot of the tomfoolery didn't go on that much.
Reason I ask is that some of the people, that's the only picture they get of what it was like.
They really believe it's all true.
How much combat danger was the hospital you were in?
Well, significant.
One Christmas party, we took some people out to a perimeter gate and got sniped at.
Sniper fire was not at all unusual.
We had regular rocket attacks.
The barracks right across the street from the hospital was getting destroyed, killed about 10 or 12 people, and damaged a whole bunch of others.
I had a one 122-millimeter rocket dutted right outside my quarters.
It was a good thing it dutted.
It would have blown my quarters to pieces.
And we had fairly regular amounts of damage from rocketry.
Was sanitation a problem?
Not on the base, per se, because we could control that.
Sanitation was a problem when you got off the base.
Of course, remember, Da Nang was one of the larger French settlements, and at one time was a very pleasant village, wonderful natural resources.
They had one area where there was a beautiful beach, and the fishing was great.
You could catch a huge lot of shrimp and things like this.

We couldn't go down there and get them and eat them because they were so contaminated with hepatitis that you stood about a 50-50 chance because most of the sewage effluent from the sewage drained right out into the bay where the shrimp people were doing all the fishing.
So fresh food from a Vietnamese standpoint was
not really obtainable.
Some people ate it, sure, but it wasn't saved.
Was the number of doctors and medics available adequate for the number of casualties encountered?
For the most part, yeah.
It's like anything else.
Casualties don't come in one at a time.
They come in in bunches of 50.
And at that time, you wished you had four or five more people.
But most of the time, as far as handling the base support and so forth, we had an adequate staff.
How was the quality of that staff, the medical personnel?
They were very good.
We had, in our particular situation, and I'm going to consider the Army too,
They had two thoracic guys.
They had two neurosurgeons.
They had ENT.
They had internal medicine and cardiology.
They had a dermatologist or two dermatologists and a large selection of general surgeons and orthopedic surgeons.
Some of which were fully trained, board eligible, and some of which were partially trained.
They came in on the very plan after they'd done two or three years of their residency.
Our staff was primarily, we had two partially trained general surgeons, and the rest were general medical officers.
And they were primarily responsible for the care of the base.
The surgical problems and other things went over to the Army, or when the Navy was there, to the Navy.
And we spent probably most of our inpatient load was concerned with the casualty staging.
Did you see a difference in quality between the drafted doctors and the career doctors?
Well, I was the only career doctor, so it's hard to compare.
There were a few, few career doctors at Cameron.
There were very few at the Army, but almost everybody there were either grafted or came in under the very plan.
I remember at that time, military service was
and very poor repute.
There was a lot of feeling, you know, over here on the stateside against the war.
And, you know, it got, a couple of my doctors told me when they went home they were, they didn't put on their uniforms because people would accost them and call them baby killers.
You know, it was really kind of nasty.
So, almost all of our people at that time were people.
What year did you actually enter the service, did you say?
I entered in 1958.
You entered in 1958.
So you didn't really know anything about what was happening in Vietnam then, because it wasn't happening yet.
No.
My first trip to Vietnam was in 1960.
We went over there on an exercise.
It was kind of a show of force.
We went over to the Philippines.
went over and spent a couple of days in Saigon, which the first time I was there, it was a beautiful city.
And then after the war started and things really got nasty, when I was back in 71, it was amazing how much it had changed.
It was just a grubby, full of refugees and shanty towns.
It was just like a completely different place.
Do you think that...
If you'd have been 10 years later, becoming a doctor in 1968, would you think you would have joined the Army, knowing what was happening in Vietnam?
Well, that's hard to say.
I know it's hypothetical.
It's a very hypothetical situation.
You'd have to assume at the same time that I'd have been 10 years younger.
and probably would have had a little more of the opinion that the young people at that time had, even in spite of the fact of having grown up in the service.
I had a pretty good idea of what life was like, but I enjoyed my service life.
My wife and I both thoroughly enjoyed it.
Did you find adequate medical supplies available to you in Vietnam?
For the most part, yeah.
There were a few things that we would run short of.
Other supplies, there's the standard everyday living.
Sometimes the VX was out of soap.
Sometimes it was out of razor blades.
You couldn't get things like that from time to time.
from medical supplies, we never really were hurting, other than maybe it being short a day or two because some supply flight from Cameron on to our main warehouse and so forth was delayed.
But we traded back and forth with the Army quite a bit.
If they were out of something, we had it.
We'd loan it to them, and then they'd pay it back, and we'd borrow something from them the next time.
There was a lot of that going on.
How about blood?
Was there always plenty of it?
Yeah, we had adequate stores of blood.
We had a blood bank, plus we had a walking blood bank.
Being on an Air Force base, most of the people there were service people in the standpoint, as opposed to combat people.
And we had a rather large pool of bodies that we could draw from if we needed blood, and we occasionally would call on them.
Was all the advanced medical equipment that was available in the United States, was that also available to you over there?
Well, if you're talking about state-of-the-art stuff, no, because we really didn't need it.
We weren't doing the kind of procedures that demanded that sort of thing.

We had adequate anesthesia equipment, we had adequate surgical equipment, but most of the stuff we were doing in-country was a patch-up, do immediate repair, and then send off to the medical centers, sometimes in the States, sometimes to Clark or Kadena, one of the larger offshore islands.
Kadena's in Okinawa, by the way.
where they would go through, and if they had a second surgical procedure, or they had to recuperate, or they had physical therapy, and all of the other things, they were given there.
And if they were reasonably bad off, they went back to the States.
I can't remember one time I was going home on leave, and we got the grand sum of two weeks leave the year we were over there.
And there was a kid who had a...
a big chunk of his skull removed, and it had the neurosurgical procedures necessary to clean it up and so forth.
But he had to go back, and they had to fit him with a titanium piece to put on it.
And because he had, in essence, an open wound, you know, where the dural was sewed, or a synthetic dural was put over it, the dural was gone, too.
and he had been cleared of his infections and so forth.
But because he was so sensitive, they wanted a medical attendant.
So I flew home with him as a medical attendant on the aerobatic system.
I took him to Walter Reed, and then went from there on.
But there were a lot of patients that we had to send.
physicians with, or if we couldn't, if there weren't any physicians available, many times we'd send a nurse, a special nurse that sat there and just took care of that patient.
Because we'd load these folks up in 141s, and, you know, you may be carrying sometimes 130s, but you may be carrying anywhere from 25 to 50 patients.
There was just a lot for the attendants there to do, so we would frequently have to
to send tenants along with them.
They were really seriously wounded.
What were the prevalent combat injuries you encountered?
Well, projectile wounds from shrapnel, bullets, wood, what have you, claymore mines, this sort of thing,
were fairly common.
Also accidental wounds.
We probably had almost as many guys damaged by 151 jeeps rolling over.
The M151 is a good
cross-country, rough terrain vehicle, but it's not worth a damn on a highway because it rolls very easily.
And we had a bunch of kids out there running around perimeter roads and running around getting these highways that roll the ditch.
So we lost a lot of, had a lot of casualties from that type of accident.
We would occasionally get some in from the Navy that had been injured.
They'd be air back to us on a helicopter.
And then we would put them on an air-vac system to get them back to the States.
But it had injuries, industrial-type injuries, catapult cables breaking and snapping, you know, double amputees and that sort of thing, and this sort of thing.
It was kind of a dangerous life on the carrier and on the flight deck.
Yeah.
And the usual run of sicknesses, everything from leukemia to, you know,
Everything that can happen in a non-wartime population happens in the others, too.
What was the prevalent non-combat disease that you saw?
Well, the prevalent non-combat casualty was from an accident.
Disease-wise, pneumonia and infection of various and sundry types.

uh you know boils and abrasions and things that weren't properly taken care of on the field that became infected and they get a cellulitis and this sort of things but usually those we were able to take care of in country um we had had several uh kids with leukemia and uh various and some of the other there was a couple of uh terrible carcinomas of the testicles and things that you
are fairly common with young adult males.
What about venereal disease?
I know that was a problem.
That was a big problem.
There was quite a lot of it.
And of course, at that time, the gonorrhea was very much penicillin resistant.
And it could be very difficult to treat.

And because our case-finding techniques, these are usually coming from Vietnamese women, and it was very difficult to track them down, to, you know, to get them treated so that they wouldn't re-infect with all the standard education things and, you know, advice on prophylaxis and that sort of stuff.
You know, it's a...
I had one guy...
asking him where he got it and how he got it, and he got it through a chain wire fence.
This gal backed up to the fence for a couple of yen there.
He got his own Elizabeth through the fence, and he got more than he bargained for.
And there was a lot of that sort of stuff.
The other big public health hazard we had there were drugs.
We had a real problem, particularly with heroin.
We don't know that it's true for a fact, but we think that it was being brought in and sold on the base as being made in Cambodia.
being brought in to the base as a means of kind of weakening the force.
I mean, it was an actual espionage type of thing.
And you could buy what in the States would be, you know, $100 worth of stuff.
You could buy it for five bucks, and you can get it.
There was no problem at all getting it, in spite of all the shakedowns we had
and getting all the monosons and breaking them down and searching and everything else.
It's just, you know, the human mind is too ingenious for us to keep from hiding it.
We had this one thing where there was a deal called Golden Flow where everybody would come in and would be told, you know, that they had to report that time at that date, you know, immediately.
for a urine check, and we were running the urines through spectrographic analysis to see if anybody was on drugs.
And it was a real hassle.
Of course, you weren't probably aware of it at that time, but that was when the drug culture was really coming on pretty strong, and the hippies and the flower children and all these folks.

a very accepted form of behavior in the young adults, particularly a lot of those GIs, the soldiers, particularly the Army types, were from poor ghetto-type families, and they had probably been exposed to a considerable amount of it.
We had a real problem keeping drugs from decreasing the combat readiness.
We spent a lot of time on it.
How about drugs among the staff, the medical staff, corpsmen and the nurses?
Had one nurse, a couple of corpsmen, no physicians that I'm aware of.
Anyway, and they all tested out long.
And most of the positions that, at least that I had, and I can only speak from my facility, positions we had were all pretty much straight shooters, and they saw the problem for what it was.
Also, they were all from the South and from the
Midwest, where that culture hadn't really caught on as strong, you know, as the California and the East Coast types were more apt to have that kind of thought.
At least that was my experience.
Was there any problems with the addiction to the pain reliever?
No, we didn't have patients long enough, really.
I mean, if they were bad enough where they needed,
narcotic analgesics, they were usually shipped out to Clark or somewhere else.
So we only used, you know, we're talking about in our casualty staging unit, we only kept them, the longest period of time was about six days.
You mentioned infections a while ago.
Was that a major problem?
Well, at that time, we had a pretty good
pretty good armamentarium with antibiotics, so it wasn't a major problem.
But we did get some resistant organisms.
And most combat wounds are dirty wounds.
Number one, when you've been out grunging around in the mud for a while, and haven't bathed in two or three weeks, other than a quick dip in the polluting stream, maybe,
and you get a wound that penetrates and goes through leather and cloth and skin and everything else and deposits all this inside, chances of infection are pretty high.
But we didn't have nearly the problem in the First World War, you know, getting shot was almost a death sentence because of infection.
We didn't have any real major problems from that standpoint, just the occasional antibiotic-resistant holding.
I know there was, like you said, a lot of diseases that you'd catch at home that caught there, too.
Was there any... How much was the disease due to the region they were in?
We saw a lot of amobiasis.
We saw giardia.
We saw...
very little in other than the echo virus and that sort of thing.
It usually went around just within the military population.
Didn't, you know, the typhoid and typhus and all the big epidemic things that were such
problems in the past we didn't have because we had excellent immunization programs.
People didn't come over to that theater unless they were adequately immunized against those diseases.
So we had a full global type thing, everything from smallpox to typhus, typhoid,
If there was an immunization possible, everybody over there had it.
So there are immunizations.
The only patient I can recall that we had any real problems with was a patient who came in with what we thought was typhoid.
And sure enough, he had typhoid, but he also didn't have any white cells because he was leukemia.
So he had very ineffective white cells.
So he had, in essence, had leukemia, which was undiagnosed.
And got challenged with a typhoid bug, came down with it, just by virtue of having a defective aneurysm, defective antibody system.
What percent, I guess, on the percentage of the servicemen that were admitted to your hospital for psychiatric reasons?
Well, we did not have a psychiatric section as such.
The psych patients were sent to over to the 9-5th where they had a closed ward holding type thing.
But I imagine
But can we break this down into major psychiatric?
By this I mean psychosis, major psychoneurosis, probably less than 2%.
But we did have some people who came in with minor problems that they needed to work out with psychosomatic illness.
that sort of thing, and that probably was more like about 10-15% of the patients we were treating.

And usually these responded to being able to sit down and talk about their problems, and a lot of them were problems from frustration because they were having problems at home, or kids were doing poorly, or they were sick, or the mama was running around, or something like this, and they were stuck there and they couldn't do anything about it, and it was just a frustration phenomenon.
So they would come up with some of these other things.
Sometimes they'd have to get emergency leaves or other types of ancillary support to kind of help them over their little crisis, and then they would come back and do a good job.
I was more interested in the number that were just going crazy because of the situation, because of the war situation.
Completely went bonkers.
Mm-hmm.
Probably of that, I'd say less than one percent.
I can only remember one or two, one or two guys, and he was probably a character and behavior disorder and not truly a psychosis.
He took his commander at gunpoint, colandeered a helicopter and flew down.
And we went out and talked with him, the base commander, and the wing commander and I went out and we sat down and negotiated with this guy and finally convinced him to give up his gun.
We sent him over to talk to the shrinks, sent him back on a medical type thing.
But I'm not convinced that this was truly a psychosis.
I think he was a character behavior disorder.
We talked with his commander later.
There had been a problem, you know, and just all along,
and ever since he'd been in the service.
Character and behavior disorders were probably the major psychiatric difficulty we ran into in the service.
Most of the guys, when they come in, they're reasonably well-screened.
How high was the survival rate for a wounded soldier?
I thought it was very high.
I couldn't give you an exact statistic.
If a guy lived to make it to the back units, he probably had a 99.9 chance of making it.
What they were in the combat aid stations and so forth, you know, the guys that got hit by a Claymore mine and had holes in everything they owned.
These fellas had kept some of them alive for a while, but a lot of them didn't make it.
There was no way they could have made it if it hadn't on the front step of the biggest hospital in the world.
What was the likely fate of an injured soldier?
Would the majority of them return to further combat?
Depends entirely on the injury.
If a fella had a minor wound, say just a

a wound involving a laceration or a simple break like a finger or a toe or something that was not incapacitated, he'd be sent back to Clark or someplace like this, allowed to heal, and sent back to Vietnam.
If it was something that was more major, a broken femur or a bad knee, injuries,
other serious wounds, intestinal wounds, and this sort of thing that required prolonged things, they'd be sent back to the States, and they were not sent back.
Unless they volunteered to come back.

I think, as I recall, the policy at that time was that if it was going to take more time, or it was going to take six months to rehabilitate them, and even though they would be able to come back for six months,
It was better to get somebody who could come in for a whole year.
It was more economical.
So they usually didn't take these people.
A lot of these people were sitting there, and they'd be wounded after they'd been in three or four months or six months, and they wouldn't be back before the tour was over anyway.
So, of course, they didn't come back.
You've mentioned AIRVAC a few times.
Can you elaborate on that a little bit and tell me how it worked?
Well, there were basically three stages of AIRVAC.
The first and probably the most critical was run by the Army, and that's the medivac system, the helicopters.
And these were medical service officers who flew the helicopters with crews that were trained specifically to take care and to pick up wounded.
and they would go out.

They were in constant radio contact, and they'd have one point where it was kind of an assembling area, and they would ship them out to pick up wounded wherever they might be, because Vietnam was not so large.
You weren't in helicopter range or someplace.
And they'd go out and pick up the wounded in the helicopters, and they were using Hueys,

four or five wounded at the same time and it then they would bring them back to uh depending on the situation now right around us they brought them right back to the 95th evac hospital but there were some other hospitals smaller hospitals like the mass units that were out in the fields further south where they weren't quite so close they would bring them back then where they would get their immediate triage

and and carried then they would be aerovac uh from there uh if it was an isolated army post by helicopter if it was they brought them to one of the larger bases that had a landing strip then they would fly by 130 back or long den or one of the several large army hospitals and they would go from there if further evacuation was warranted

then they would go from there through us, through the casualty staging units, which were at, uh, they had one at Cameron, they had one at Da Nang, and they had one at, uh, at, uh, Saigon, at Townsend.
And these people would be processed through them, and from there they would go to either Japan, uh, Okinawa, or Clark, and then they would either stay there overnight,
or maybe for four or five days, depending on their condition, and then they would be put on a long haul and be brought back to the States.
So, you know, it would depend on the nature of the wound and the nature of the problem as to where they would stop in these intermediate ways.
You know, if a guy got a bullet that creased his shoulder or a fragment tear or something on his shoulder, he might go to the Italian aid station and fix him up
And that would be the minute of flying back to his unit.
That would be about all there would be to it.
But for the more seriously wounded, it really, we had guys that were seriously wounded and were back in the United States at a major military hospital in four days.
So it's a good system.
And that's with immediate, that's with care and treatment and everything along the way.
That was one of the biggest improvements made over the Korean War.
Can you think of any other improvements that were made in the Vietnam War over the Korean?
Primarily, of course, we had a better selection of antibiotics.
During the Korean War, they had penicillin, they had streptomycin, they had sulfonyl.
And that was essentially it.
The later part, then, they had some chloromycetins and other things.
We had a much more, much broader spectrum of antibiotics.
Korea, they were just experimenting with vascular surgery.
That's how Denton Cooley and some of them got their start on vascular surgery, carrying war injuries in Korea.
In Vietnam, vascular surgery was
already pretty far along, and there was a lot of things done at the knife at the back and so forth.
The major vascular injuries were repaired by just, you know, resecting the damaged artery and putting it in the graft, and we didn't have that in Korea.
The systems were faster in Korea.
If you were wounded, they put you on a DC-3, a C-47, or a C-54, lead you to Japan, which took about two or four hours.
And then from Japan back, it was almost all reset-type airbag things or going back by ship.
I was middle of the ship.
And so it was a long time between the time you got there to where you were to get definitive care in the final form.
Whereas in the Aerovac system with larger jet aircraft, they would haul more and haul them a lot faster.
As I said, it was sometimes a matter of four days before somebody was in the stateside hospital getting that subspecialty super care that they needed.
I can't think of a great deal of warfare from the standpoint of the guy in the trench.
It hasn't changed just a hell of a bunch.
Hearing it just a little bit further, can you think of any lessons that were learned in medicine as a result of Vietnam?
That's a pretty profound question.
I don't know.
Maybe I didn't word it right.
No.
I think that you worded it right, but it covers a multitude of things.
I think we learned that our Aerovac system was a good system, and it could be refined maybe even a little more.
And we learned the importance of maintaining an Aerovac system.

From purely the medical standpoint, the need for having well-equipped, transportable, pre-assembled hospitals, I think, was something that they learned out of that, because it wasn't until well along in the Vietnam War that they came up with these things.
They were going to have to kind of do make do.
That whole base went up in about two weeks, and the hospital put it together in a couple of days.
But everything was pre-packed.
They just brought it off the ship, put it on the barge, hauled it up to the crane, put it in, and dropped it in place.
And they hooked them all together like a giant tinker toy.
And so they did come up with that lesson, the importance of having these things that
rapidly able to be moved and put up in place, and if necessary, torn down and taken someplace else.
The necessity for the immunization procedures was well proven in World War II, and that wasn't exactly a new lesson.
It was just like many things, one of the things we had to relearn.
The real basic question is that war is hell and it doesn't make any difference how well you're equipped and everything, that there are a lot of people suffering and a lot of people dying.
It's best to avoid one if you can.
I think that's kind of a general summation of it.
Someone mentioned that intensive care units in hospitals were improved.
That's not fact-based.
What do you think about that?
Yeah, they are.
The intensive care equipment that we have, and a lot of the procedures, too, have changed since then.
We still had a one-on-one nurse, and a good, smart intensive care nurse doesn't need a whole bunch of stuff to tell her that the patient's good or the patient's going bad.
I'm a firm believer in looking at folks, you know.

And the sophistication of today, you know, where you can hook a guy up to an automatic blood pressure impulse and all this stuff and have it all read out in a purized area means that, you know, you can kind of divvy up the workload.
I don't really know, with the exception of some of the newer drugs that we have,
We do any better job now in intensive care than we did then.
Just our basic equipment is easier to use.
It's a little more reliable.
But when it comes down to the one-on-one of a nurse and a patient and a physician taking care of them, I just don't know that we do any better now than we did then.
I've done a lot of reading on this, on some of the statistics and stuff in Vietnam.
The majority of the deaths resulted from injuries to the face and neck region.
Can you think of any way that can be prevented or some kind of a... Well, the reason that's true, if you think about combat and what happens to a guy, number one, he's wearing a flak jacket.
Most of them had on flak jackets.
So the thorax is pretty well

protected and they're hiding in a hole and what's exposed the head and the shoulder that's why most of the injuries are based on that all right one other thing that crossed my mind when i was reading all this most of the death like you said if they got to the hospital they usually survived so most of the deaths were due to if the helicopters can get in there quick enough are
Well, I'm sure there were some of that.
Most of the deaths were because they were so badly damaged that they couldn't survive no matter where they were.
I think if they received what I would call a non-lethal injury, something that wasn't going to kill them regardless, their chances of survival were pretty good.
But if you've ever seen anybody who's been hit by an AK-47 about six times, or has been
blown up by a Claymore mine, there's very damn little anybody can do for them.
And they may still be alive, but not for long.
And it doesn't make any difference where they are.
So even if their buddy next to them was trained in first aid, that's what I was thinking.
Why didn't their soldier be trained in first aid?
The soldier was trained in first aid.
They were?
Sure.
They had corpsmen right there with them all the time who were really, some of those corpsmen were really sharp.
And they got to do damn good.
But every GI going through training who received first aid, he knew how to do a, or was told, he maybe didn't know how, but they knew how to do tracheostomy.
